title: Martianus Capella, De nuptiis and other texts
contents: Martianus Capella, De nuptiis Philologiae et Mercurii; some other short texts.

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: The other scribe added a note on musical pitches, and two sets of schemes regarding syllogistic propositions. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: A line separates the sets of examples of syllogisms. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: We know who one of these scribes was – Rather of Verona (890-974) added a copy of a letter at the base of the page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail):: For example, using a ‘mixed’ syllogism: ‘Whether the knowledge of discussing is useful. If good discussion is useful, the science of discussing well is useful. But good discussion is useful... Therefore dialectic is useful.’ http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 31r: example of a very full commentary added in the margin. The book is 307 mm high. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail): In the second set of schemes lines connect terms of the propositions and conclusion in order to indicate how the argument is constructed. Visualising the argument in this way helps understand why it is valid. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail): The scheme is evidence of a reader trying to understand the steps made by Dialectic in reaching this conclusion; the scheme illustrates the reader’s thought process! http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

title: Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philologiae et Mercurii and some additional material.
origin: North France, in part probably Reims

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 4v: Text in the box, drawn by us: ‘According to Calcidius, entelechy is perfecta aetas, completed lifetime. According to Aristotle, it is interpreted as absolute perfection. Plato, on the other hand, says that entelechy is the anima mundi, the soul of the world.’ http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417

title: Aristotelis periermeniae and other texts
contents: Aristotle, Periermeneias (On Interpetation), ff. 1r.-12r;  Augustinus, De dialectica, ff. 12r-21v; two short fragments, discussion of ousia (essence). f. 22r-23v; Categoriae decem, preceded by Alcuin’s prologue dedicated to Charlemagne, ff. 24r-39v; fragments and notes, ff. 39v-45v; Porphyry, Isagoge,  ff. 46r-52v; Boethius, De Trinitate ad Symmachum,  ff. 53r-57r; Boethius, De substantia ad Johannem Diaconum, ff. 57v-62v; Boethius, Adversus Nestorium et Eutychen, ff. 62v-70v; Apuleius, Peri hermeneias, ff.71r-80v; Boethius, Commentary on Peri hermeneias, ff. 80v -81r.

folioParts.fpdescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v: Here you can see how a little ‘Porphyrian tree’ has been added in the inner margin even when there was hardly space. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v:Here you can see how a later reader added large ‘NOTA’ signs as tiemarks, to clear up the puzzle of where to place the gloss. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v:Here you can see how a first reader went really fancyfull with inventing a new tiemark, and how a later reader drew a line between text and gloss to mark them off a bit more clearly. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 25v: ‘Heiricus magister Remigii fecit has glossas’. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Aristotle’s On Interpretation deals with the relationship between words, reality and logic.https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

title: Six Comedies and other texts
contents: I. Publius Terentius Afer, Comoediae sex (f. 1-26). — II. Quintus Horatius Flaccus, Opera (f. 27-56). — III. M. Annaeus Lucanus, Pharsalia (f. 57-94). — Juvenalis, Satyrae (f. 95-111). — IV. Martianus Capella, De nuptiis Mercuri et Philologiae (f. 112-155).

title: Libri Missalis fragmenta. – Boethii in Aristotelem de Interpretatione Commentarius. – L. Apuleius Madaurensis de Interpretatione
contents: Boethius, Commentary on Aristotle’s De Interpretatione (f. 2-38); Apuleius, De Interpretatione (f. 38-41); some unrelated fragments from a missal.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail): Square of opposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail): Square of opposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail), Affirmative and negative propositions: In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and particular negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail), Contradictory Relationships: The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictoriae’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then the proposition ‘some men are just’ cannot be true. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail), Contrary Relationships: The placement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail), Subaltern Relationships: Finally, reading alongside the sides of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’ (placed at the top of the square), is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition, ‘some men are just’ (placed at the bottom of the square), must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’, is true, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’, must also be true. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684

folios.foliodescription: Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315 (605), p. 139: representation of Porphyry’s five predicables. https://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/list/one/sbe/0315

folioParts.fpdescription: Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p.6: The text has been carefully corrected, here ‘ad’ has been corrected to ‘ab’ and ‘actenus’ to ‘hactenus’. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p. 6: Here small squiggles have been added in the margin alongside the text; these are rudimentary quotation marks indicating original text from the Isagoge, the subject of Boethius’ commentary. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p. 6: Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). The glossator describes these as ‘confusus ordo’, the confusion of order, and ‘repetitio’, repetition, respectively. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315

title: De syllogismis categoricis and other text(s)

title: Commentarium Boetii in periermenias librum Aristotelis – S. X
contents: Boethius, Commentary on Aristotle's Periermenias; Apuleius, Liber periermenias (f. 53); Oratio Ciceronis in Salustium (f. 58v); Oratio Salustii in Ciceronem (f. 61r); Controversia Deoderici, Metensis episcopi, in Karolum (f. 62r); Gerbertus ex persona Karoli (f. 62v); Boethius, Liber divisionis (f. 64v); Boethius, Liber de topicis differentiis (f. 74r); Communis speculatio de rethoricae cognatione (f.101r); Boethius, Introductio ad categoricos syllogismos (f. 105r); Boethius, Libri tres de hypotheticis syllogismis (f. 145v); Hyginus, Liber de imaginibus coeli (f. 170v); Epistola Alexandri regis ad Aristotelem, etc. (f. 201r); Verba Dandami, brachmanorum summi (f. 209r). Commonitorium Pallidii [ad Karolum Magnum]" (f.215r).

title: Severini Boethii Opera. – Alcuinus de Dialectica
contents: Boethius, De divisione (f.1r-8v); pseudo-Boethius, De definitione (f.9r-16v); Boethius, De syllogismo hypothetico (f.17-44v); Boethius, De syllogismo categorico (f.45r-67r); Boethius, Antepraedicamenta (f.67v-89v); Alcuin of York, De dialectica (f.90r-103v)

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8v: INCIPIT ARS DIALECTICA ALCHOINI PHILOSOPHI. AD KAROLUM MAGNUM. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 63r: List of propositions. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 89v: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 89v: Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 90v: Ch(arles): How many species are there in dialectic? A(lcuin): The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is … . http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 90v: Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 103v: A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84: On f. 8v we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 32v: An example of numbers (‘ii’), from f. 32v. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 13r: ‘Retro in libro topicorum iii’: ‘Back in book III of the Topics’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 14r: ‘Retro in fine libri tercium topicorum ciceronis’: ‘Back in the end of the third book of Cicero’s Topics’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 44v: two sets of rubrics (written in red) indicate that one text has ended and that another will begin on the next page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 44v: two sets of rubrics (written in red) indicate that one text has ended and that another will begin on the next page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8r: a decorated initial is used for the first word of a new text. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84: Furthermore, a new set of quire gatherings starts on f. 17r; from this point to the end of the manuscript quires are numbered with numbers, not letters. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

title: De inventione and other text(s)
contents: Cicero, De inventione (f.1r-50v); pseudo-Alexander the Great, Letter to Aristotle (f.50v-58v); pseudo-Cicero, Rhetorica ad Herennium (f.59r-112v)

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r: These schemata summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

folioParts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: Here the glossator introduces the characters in the conversation. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: ‘Ecce’, ‘Look’, the glossator writes – ‘an example of induction’ . http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: The glossator indicates who is speaking between the lines (‘Aspasia’s words’, ’Xenophon’s wife responds’ etc). These names and characters may have been unfamiliar to the reader, so these cues helped them follow the text. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r: These schemata summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

title: Aristoteles, Praedicamenta and other texts
contents: Aristoteles, Praedicamenta (f.1r-4r), Periermenias (f. 4v-15r). - Liber sex principium (f. 15v-23v). - Boethius, De divisione (f. 24-35v), Topica (f. 36-68v). Aristoteles, De sophisticis elenchis (f. 69r-92v), Topica (f. 93r-164r), Analytica priora (f.164v-217v), Analytica posteriora (f. 218r-249v), Praedicamenta (f. 250r-259v).

folios.foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 218r: Opening of Analytica Posteriora. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 164v: Opening of Analytica Priora. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 17r (detail): Portrait of a master and student. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

folioParts.fpdescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 117r: portrait of a master teaching a student. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

folios.foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 69r: a column for commentary on the left of the tekst, and two columns on the right. The lower margin is also typically large to house large amounts of notes and comments. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

folioParts.fpdescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v: A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v: In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v. A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v. In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

title: Petrus Abaelard,  Berengarius Pictavensis and other texts
contents: Letters of Abelard, Heloise, Berengar of Poitiers, Cassiodorus, Stephen of Tournai and two treatises on the composition of letters (artes dictaminis)

folios.foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 2923 (mid 13th c.), f. 49r: Abelard, Apologia seu fidei confessio ‘Universis’ (1141). https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b84386206
